metadata.title: Opioid Overdose
learning_objectives: Recognize opioid toxidrome (respiratory depression, miosis, decreased LOC)
Understand naloxone goal: adequate breathing, NOT full consciousness

changelog.v3.0_enhanced: New scenario with Blueprint Structure Enhancement v2: matching config, clinical anchors, consequence templates, ECG standardization. Deterioration timing 5/9/13 min. 20-minute duration.

dispatch_info.additional_info: Found unresponsive in bathroom stall, not breathing well

scene_description.location: Public park bathroom, patient slumped on toilet in locked stall
scene_description.safety: Security guard opened door, scene safe, needle visible on floor
scene_description.access: Ground level, narrow bathroom, will need to move patient for stretcher access
scene_description.bystanders: Security guard present, no witnesses to drug use

patient_profile.name: Tomáš
patient_profile.personality: Unresponsive initially. After naloxone: may be confused, irritable, anxious, possibly combative if over-reversed

initial.student_sees: You find a young man slumped on a toilet in a bathroom stall. He's completely unresponsive - his head is hanging forward, arms limp at his sides. His skin is pale with a grayish-blue tinge, especially around his lips and fingertips. You can barely see his chest moving - maybe 4 very shallow breaths per minute. When you lift his eyelid, his pupils are tiny pinpoints, barely visible. There's a syringe on the floor near his foot, and you can see fresh needle marks on his left forearm. The security guard says: 'I check these bathrooms every hour. He wasn't here an hour ago.' The patient doesn't respond to voice or sternal rub.
initial.appearance: Young male, unresponsive, cyanotic, agonal breathing, pinpoint pupils, needle/syringe visible, track marks on arm
initial.clinical_note: OPIOID OVERDOSE - classic toxidrome: respiratory depression (RR 4), CNS depression (GCS 3), miosis (pinpoint pupils). CRITICAL HYPOXIA (SpO2 78%). VENTILATE FIRST - naloxone doesn't work on dead patients. After oxygenating, give naloxone titrated to respiratory effort, NOT to full consciousness.

improving.student_sees: After your interventions, the patient is breathing better. His respiratory rate has increased and his color is improving - less blue around the lips. His eyes are flickering, and he's starting to move slightly. He groans when you call his name. He's not fully awake - drowsy and confused - but he's BREATHING adequately. That's the goal. 'Wha... where am I?' he mumbles, looking around confused. He doesn't seem to remember what happened.
improving.appearance: Drowsy but rousable, breathing adequately (RR 12-16), color improving, confused but responsive
improving.clinical_note: GOAL ACHIEVED: Patient breathing adequately. He doesn't need to be fully awake - just breathing. Full reversal risks acute withdrawal (vomiting, agitation, combativeness) and patient may leave AMA and re-use. Drowsy but breathing is the target.

deteriorating.student_sees: The patient's condition is worsening - or the naloxone is wearing off. His breathing is slowing down again, becoming shallow and irregular. His color is deteriorating - more cyanotic. He's less responsive than before. This could be re-sedation as naloxone wears off (shorter duration than many opioids) or inadequate initial reversal.
deteriorating.appearance: Re-sedation occurring, breathing slowing, becoming less responsive, cyanosis returning
deteriorating.clinical_note: RE-SEDATION - naloxone duration (30-90 min) often shorter than opioid duration (hours). May need repeat naloxone. Continue to monitor closely. If fentanyl involved, may need much higher naloxone doses.

critical.student_sees: CRITICAL: The patient is not breathing. His chest is still. His lips are blue-gray. He's completely unresponsive. No pulse palpable at the wrist. This is respiratory arrest progressing to cardiac arrest if not immediately reversed.
critical.appearance: Apneic, pulseless or barely palpable pulse, profound cyanosis, imminent cardiac arrest
critical.clinical_note: Respiratory arrest from opioid-induced respiratory depression. Without immediate BVM ventilation and naloxone, will progress to cardiac arrest from hypoxia. CPR may be needed.

airway.initial: Patent but at risk - patient not protecting, head position obstructing, may need repositioning

breathing.initial: RR 4, shallow, barely visible chest movement, inadequate tidal volume, cyanosis
breathing.deteriorating: RR declining again as naloxone wears off

circulation.initial: HR 52 (bradycardia from hypoxia), BP 88/52, weak pulse, cool peripheries, CRT 4 seconds
circulation.improving: HR 72, BP 105/68, stronger pulse, warming up

disability.initial: GCS 3 (E1V1M1), unresponsive to all stimuli, pupils 1mm bilateral (pinpoint - classic opioid sign)
disability.improving: GCS 10-12, drowsy but rousable, following commands, pupils 3mm reactive
disability.note: Pupils dilate toward normal as opioid reversed

exposure.needle_marks: Fresh injection site left antecubital fossa, older track marks on both forearms
exposure.paraphernalia: Syringe on floor, possibly tourniquet nearby

sample_history.medications: Unknown - likely opioid use disorder, unknown if on methadone/buprenorphine program
sample_history.past_history: Unknown - track marks suggest chronic IV drug use
sample_history.events: Security guard: 'Found him about 5 minutes ago when I did my rounds. He wasn't here an hour ago. I see a lot of overdoses in this park.'

opioid_toxidrome.differential: Consider: other sedative overdose, head injury, hypoglycemia, stroke - but classic triad with needle marks = opioid overdose

interpretation.mechanism: Hypoxia causes bradycardia (unlike most other causes which cause tachycardia)

ecg_findings.teaching_point: Bradycardia in overdose is usually from HYPOXIA, not direct opioid effect. Treat the hypoxia (ventilate!) and heart rate will improve. ECG useful to check for prolonged QTc if methadone involved. Don't delay ventilation for ECG.

naloxone.mechanism: Competitively blocks opioid receptors, reverses respiratory depression

dosing.intranasal: 2mg IN (one spray each nostril) if no IV
dosing.titration_goal: Adequate respiratory effort (RR >12), NOT full consciousness

pharmacokinetics.note: Duration often SHORTER than opioid - re-sedation common

side_effects: Acute opioid withdrawal (if dependent): nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, agitation, tachycardia, hypertension
warnings: VENTILATE FIRST - naloxone doesn't work on dead patients
Over-reversal causes withdrawal, vomiting (aspiration risk), combativeness, patient leaving AMA
Re-sedation common - monitor for at least 2 hours
Fentanyl may require much higher doses

scenario_specific_response.patient_response_titrated: Patient starts breathing better. Becomes drowsy but rousable. Opens eyes to voice. Confused: 'Where am I? What happened?' May be irritable or anxious.
scenario_specific_response.patient_response_over_reversed: Patient suddenly fully awake, agitated, possibly combative. 'Get off me!' May vomit (aspiration risk). May try to leave. May become hostile.
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Reverses opioid effects at receptor level. Goal: adequate breathing, patient can protect airway.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Titrate to BREATHING, not consciousness. A drowsy patient who is breathing is safer than a fully awake patient who bolts and re-uses.

bag_valve_mask.indication: Respiratory support before and during naloxone effect

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Provides oxygen and ventilation while waiting for naloxone to work
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: VENTILATE FIRST. Naloxone takes 1-2 minutes to work. Patient needs oxygen NOW. BVM bridges the gap.

scenario_specific_response.note: Oxygen alone insufficient - patient not breathing adequately, needs BVM

bvm_then_naloxone.sequence: BVM ventilation → SpO2 improves → Naloxone → Patient starts breathing spontaneously
bvm_then_naloxone.clinical_effect: Optimal sequence - patient oxygenated throughout, smooth reversal

vital_changes.SpO2: May drop further during 1-2 min waiting for naloxone to work

naloxone_without_bvm.clinical_effect: Dangerous - patient hypoxic during naloxone onset time

over_reversal.patient_response: Fully awake, agitated, vomiting, trying to leave, possibly combative
over_reversal.clinical_effect: Acute withdrawal precipitated - patient uncomfortable, aspiration risk, may leave AMA and re-use

5min.description: Near-apneic, profound hypoxia, bradycardia worsening, imminent arrest

9min.description: Respiratory arrest, severe bradycardia, hypotensive, will arrest within minutes

13min.description: Cardiac arrest from hypoxia - requires CPR

critical_harm.name: excessive_naloxone

if_given.patient_response: Patient suddenly fully awake, agitated, vomiting, diaphoretic, tachycardic. 'What did you give me?! Get away from me!' May become combative. High risk of vomiting and aspiration.
if_given.clinical_effect: Acute opioid withdrawal precipitated. Patient uncomfortable, aspiration risk, will likely refuse transport, may re-use immediately.

critical_harm.teaching_point: Titrate naloxone to BREATHING, not consciousness. 0.4mg, wait 2 minutes, repeat if needed. Goal RR >12, not GCS 15.

worsens.name: flumazenil
worsens.why_wrong: This is opioid overdose, not benzodiazepine. And flumazenil can cause seizures.

if_given.clinical_effect: No effect - flumazenil reverses benzodiazepines, not opioids. If patient also took benzos, flumazenil may cause seizures.

worsens.teaching_point: Naloxone reverses OPIOIDS. Flumazenil reverses BENZODIAZEPINES. Different receptors, different antidotes. Also, flumazenil causes seizures in benzo-dependent patients.

neutral.name: glucose
neutral.why_check: Reasonable to check glucose in any unresponsive patient

if_given.clinical_effect: No effect if glucose normal. But checking glucose is good practice in altered mental status.

neutral.teaching_point: Checking glucose in unresponsive patient is good practice. But this presentation (pinpoint pupils, needle marks, RR 4) is classic opioid overdose.

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Needle safety, BSI, no other hazards
Identifies triad: respiratory depression + CNS depression + miosis
MUST ventilate BEFORE or WHILE giving naloxone
Goal RR >12, patient breathing adequately, NOT necessarily fully awake
Recognizes naloxone may wear off before opioid

critical_actions_checklist.action: Transport decision with harm reduction approach

common_errors.teaching_point: VENTILATE FIRST - naloxone takes 1-2 minutes to work, patient needs oxygen NOW
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Naloxone doesn't work on dead patients. Ventilate first, naloxone second.
A drowsy patient who's breathing is safer than an awake patient who vomits, fights, and leaves to use again.

common_errors.teaching_point: Naloxone lasts 30-90 minutes, opioids last hours - re-sedation common
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Naloxone wears off. The opioid doesn't. Watch for round two.

common_errors.teaching_point: May need repeat doses, especially with fentanyl
common_errors.clinical_anchor: One dose may not be enough. Fentanyl can laugh at 0.4mg naloxone.

common_errors.teaching_point: ABC always applies - opioid overdose is primarily a respiratory emergency
common_errors.clinical_anchor: This is a breathing problem first, a drug problem second. Treat the A and B.

common_errors.teaching_point: Harm reduction approach improves outcomes - treat with dignity
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Addiction is a disease. Judgment doesn't save lives, naloxone does.

consequence_templates.template: BVM ventilation was never provided. {patient_name} had a respiratory rate of 4 and SpO2 of 78%. While waiting for naloxone to work (1-2 minutes), his brain was severely hypoxic. Naloxone reverses opioid effects, but it cannot reverse the brain damage from prolonged hypoxia.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Opioid overdose deaths are from respiratory depression and hypoxia. Ventilation provides immediate oxygenation while waiting for naloxone to take effect.

consequence_templates.template: Naloxone was given at {actual_time} minutes. While ventilation may have supported oxygenation, delayed naloxone prolonged the period of respiratory depression and required continued manual ventilation.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Prompt naloxone administration restores spontaneous respiration, reducing need for prolonged assisted ventilation.

consequence_templates.template: Naloxone was given BEFORE ventilation was established. During the 1-2 minutes while naloxone took effect, {patient_name}'s SpO2 of 78% continued to fall. The sequence should be: VENTILATE → naloxone → continue support until breathing adequate.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Naloxone onset is 1-2 minutes IV. During this time, an apneic patient continues to be hypoxic. BVM ventilation bridges this gap.

optimal_sequence: Begin BVM ventilation with high-flow oxygen
THEN give naloxone while continuing ventilation support

scoring.optimal: Immediately opened airway, initiated BVM ventilation, gave naloxone while ventilating, verbalized: 'Need to oxygenate first - naloxone takes a minute to work.'
scoring.acceptable: Provided ventilation and naloxone nearly simultaneously.
scoring.suboptimal: Gave naloxone first, then started ventilation after brief delay.
scoring.dangerous: Gave naloxone without ever ventilating, or significant delay to oxygenation.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Naloxone doesn't work on dead patients. Ventilate first, reverse second.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Opioid overdose kills by stopping breathing. Naloxone is the antidote, but it takes 1-2 minutes to work. During that time, patient needs oxygen. BVM ventilation is THE immediate life-saving intervention. Naloxone is second.

critical_decision_points.description: Appropriate naloxone dosing to avoid over-reversal

scoring.optimal: Started with 0.4mg, assessed response, repeated incrementally, stopped when RR >12 even though patient still drowsy. Verbalized: 'Goal is breathing, not full awakening.'
scoring.acceptable: Gave appropriate doses, achieved adequate breathing.
scoring.suboptimal: Gave larger initial dose, patient uncomfortable but not severely over-reversed.
scoring.dangerous: Large bolus (2mg+) causing severe withdrawal, vomiting, combativeness.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Titrate to breathing, not consciousness. Drowsy and breathing beats awake and vomiting.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Naloxone goal: RR >12, patient protecting airway. NOT GCS 15. Over-reversal causes acute withdrawal (vomiting, agitation, tachycardia, hypertension), aspiration risk, patient leaving AMA, and immediate re-use. A drowsy patient who's breathing adequately is the optimal endpoint.

critical_decision_points.description: Recognizing and planning for naloxone wearing off

scoring.optimal: Verbalized awareness that naloxone may wear off before opioid, planned for monitoring, prepared for repeat dosing.
scoring.acceptable: Monitored patient, recognized when re-sedation began, repeated naloxone.
scoring.suboptimal: Assumed single dose sufficient, didn't actively monitor.
scoring.dangerous: Left patient after initial reversal, no monitoring plan.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Naloxone wears off in 30-90 minutes. Fentanyl lasts hours. Plan for round two.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Naloxone duration: 30-90 minutes. Many opioids (especially fentanyl): 4-24 hours. Re-sedation is COMMON and EXPECTED. All opioid overdose patients need at least 2 hours of monitoring. Transport is essential even if patient refuses initially.

key_concepts: VENTILATE FIRST - naloxone doesn't work on dead patients
Opioid toxidrome: respiratory depression + CNS depression + miosis (pinpoint pupils)
Re-sedation is common - naloxone wears off before opioid does
Harm reduction approach: treat with dignity, don't judge
clinical_pearls: Bradycardia in overdose is from HYPOXIA - will improve with oxygenation
Fentanyl may require much higher naloxone doses (10mg+)
Pinpoint pupils help distinguish opioid OD from other causes of unresponsiveness
Over-reversal causes vomiting (aspiration risk) and patient leaving AMA to use again
0.4mg IV, wait 2-3 minutes, repeat - not large bolus doses
